issues.title: [BUG] mlflow.genai.datasets.create_dataset throws ConnectionError when registering dataset
issues.body:
### Issues Policy acknowledgement

- [x] I have read and agree to submit bug reports in accordance with the [issues policy](https://www.github.com/mlflow/mlflow/blob/master/ISSUE_POLICY.md)

### Where did you encounter this bug?

Local machine

### MLflow version

- Client: 1.x.y
- Tracking server: 3.5.1


### System information

- **OS Platform and Distribution (e.g., Linux Ubuntu 16.04)**: windows
- **Python version**: 3.11
- **yarn version, if running the dev UI**:


### Describe the problem

When attempting to create a dataset, mlflow is throwing a connection error. Is it a bug or am I missing some step ?

Reference - https://mlflow.org/docs/3.5.1/genai/datasets/end-to-end-workflow/#step-4-create-an-evaluation-dataset



### Tracking information

<!-- PLEASE KEEP BACKTICKS AND CHECK PREVIEW -->
```shell
MLflow version: 3.5.1
Tracking URI: http://localhost:5000/
```


### Code to reproduce issue

```
import mlflow
from mlflow.genai.datasets import create_dataset

mlflow.set_tracking_uri("http://localhost:5000")
mlflow.set_experiment("dummy")

print(mlflow.get_experiment_by_name("dummy").experiment_id)

with mlflow.start_run():
    mlflow.log_param("param1", "value1")

dataset = create_dataset(
    name="ag_news_classifier_sample",
    experiment_id=mlflow.get_experiment_by_name("dummy").experiment_id,
    tags={"stage": "testing"},
)
```

### Stack trace

[stack_trace.txt](https://github.com/user-attachments/files/23447515/stack_trace.txt)

### Other info / logs

<!-- PLEASE KEEP BACKTICKS AND CHECK PREVIEW -->
```
REPLACE_ME
```

### Issues Policy acknowledgement

### Where did you encounter this bug?

Local machine

### MLflow version

- Client: 3.5.1
- Tracking server: use docker compose built.Here is the docker_compose.yaml
```
services:
  postgres:
    image: postgres:15
    container_name: mlflow-postgres
    env_file:
      - .env
    volumes:
      - ./pgdata:/var/lib/postgresql/data
#    ports:
#      - "5432:5432"
    healthcheck:
      test: ["CMD-SHELL", "pg_isready -U ${POSTGRES_USER}"]
      interval: 5s
      timeout: 3s
      retries: 10

  minio:
    image: minio/minio:latest
    container_name: mlflow-minio
    env_file:
      - .env
    volumes:
      - ./minio-data:/data
    command: server /data --console-address ":9001"
    ports:
      - "9000:9000"
      - "9001:9001"
    healthcheck:
      test: ["CMD", "curl", "-f", "http://localhost:${MINIO_PORT}/minio/health/live"]
      interval: 5s
      timeout: 3s
      retries: 20

  create-bucket:
    image: minio/mc:latest
    container_name: mlflow-create-bucket
    depends_on:
      minio:
        condition: service_healthy
    env_file:
      - .env
    entrypoint: >
      /bin/sh -c '
        mc alias set myminio http://${MINIO_HOST}:${MINIO_PORT} \
          ${MINIO_ROOT_USER} ${MINIO_ROOT_PASSWORD} &&
        mc mb --ignore-existing myminio/${MINIO_BUCKET:-mlflow}
      '
    restart: "no"

  mlflow:
    image: [ghcr.io/mlflow/mlflow:${MLFLOW_VERSION}](http://ghcr.io/mlflow/mlflow:$%7BMLFLOW_VERSION%7D)
    container_name: mlflow-server
    depends_on:
      postgres:
        condition: service_healthy
      minio:
        condition: service_healthy
      create-bucket:
        condition: service_completed_successfully
    env_file:
      - .env
    environment:
      HTTP_PROXY: http://192.168.80.80:15732/
      HTTPS_PROXY: http://192.168.80.80:15732/

    command: >
      /bin/bash -c "
        pip install --no-cache-dir psycopg2-binary boto3 &&
        mlflow server \
          --backend-store-uri ${MLFLOW_BACKEND_STORE_URI} \
          --default-artifact-root ${MLFLOW_DEFAULT_ARTIFACT_ROOT} \
          --host ${MLFLOW_HOST} \
          --port ${MLFLOW_PORT}
      "
    ports:
      - "${MLFLOW_PORT}:${MLFLOW_PORT}"
```

issues.title: [BUG]runner.run_streamed with handoff creates separate traces for chained agents
issues.body:
### Issues Policy acknowledgement

- [x] I have read and agree to submit bug reports in accordance with the [issues policy](https://www.github.com/mlflow/mlflow/blob/master/ISSUE_POLICY.md)

### Where did you encounter this bug?

Local machine

### MLflow version

Local machine
### MLflow version
mlflow 3.5.1
### System information
## üêõ Bug Report: `runner.run_streamed` with `handoff` creates separate traces for chained agents
### üîç Summary
When chaining multiple Agents using the OpenAI Agents SDK **`handoff` mechanism** and executing the sequence via **`runner.run_streamed`**, the expected behavior of a single, continuous trace is not achieved. Instead, each Agent in the chain produces a **separate, independent MLflow Trace**, breaking the end-to-end visibility of the agent execution flow.
### üìù Description
We are utilizing the ` OpenAI Agents SDK ` to build complex workflows where one Agent's output is passed to the next Agent (chained using `handoff`).
When executing this chain using the streaming method, **`runner.run_streamed()`**, the MLflow tracing functionality appears to reset or re-initialize a new run/trace context at the transition point between Agents (i.e., where the `handoff` occurs).
**Expected Behavior:**
The entire sequence of agent calls, from the initial trigger through all subsequent `handoff` steps, should be recorded as a **single, unified MLflow Trace/Run** that captures the entire conversation flow, including intermediate tool calls and final outputs.
**Actual Behavior:**
The execution results in **$N$ distinct MLflow Traces** (where $N$ is the number of agents in the chain). Each trace only captures the activity of the specific Agent responsible for that segment of execution. This makes debugging and analyzing the complete, end-to-end agent logic extremely difficult.
### Describe the problem
Three Agents were connected in series, resulting in three traces


### System information

- **OS Platform and Distribution (e.g., Linux Ubuntu 16.04)**:macos
- **Python version**:3.11
- **yarn version, if running the dev UI**:


### Describe the problem

Three Agents were connected in series, resulting in three traces

The following script can reproduce the problem

[agent_coordinator.py](https://github.com/user-attachments/files/23440090/agent_coordinator.py)

### Tracking information

<!-- PLEASE KEEP BACKTICKS AND CHECK PREVIEW -->
```shell
REPLACE_ME
```


### Code to reproduce issue

<!-- PLEASE KEEP BACKTICKS AND CHECK PREVIEW -->
```
REPLACE_ME
```


### Stack trace

<!-- PLEASE KEEP BACKTICKS AND CHECK PREVIEW -->
```
REPLACE_ME
```


### Other info / logs

<!-- PLEASE KEEP BACKTICKS AND CHECK PREVIEW -->
```

```

I propose adding webhook functionality for key events originating from MLflow Tracing. An automated monitoring and notification system is essential for reliable Agent service operations. This would minimize service downtime and maximize operational efficiency.

issues.body:
### MLflow version

3.5.1

### Describe the problem

https://github.com/mlflow/mlflow/blob/448a622eb1ee14b6b25a002c954c0c7dce4976af/mlflow/server/js/src/shared/web-shared/genai-traces-table/hooks/useActiveEvaluation.tsx#L16-L28

When opening a URL with a `selectedEvaluationId` parameter, when the UI is not yet loaded (for example in a new tab), the code will attempt to find it before the evaluations are loaded, the evaluation is not found, and the parameter is reset. 

This method should be executed after the evaluations load.

issues.title: [FR] Serialization parity between `local` and `virtualenv` values for `env_manager` in spark_udf

labels.name: area/scoring
labels.description: MLflow Model server, model deployment tools, Spark UDFs

labels.name: domain/deep-learning
labels.description: Feature requests for Deep Learning use cases

labels.name: domain/classical-ml
labels.description: Feature requests for Classical ML use cases

labels.name: domain/platform
labels.description: Feature requests about platform foundation, not specific to a problem domain

issues.body:
### Willingness to contribute

Yes. I would be willing to contribute this feature with guidance from the MLflow community.

### Proposal Summary

The `mlflow.pyfunc.spark_udf` high level API has different I/O limitations depending on the `env_manager` parameter used (`"local"` vs `"virtualenv"`). Since one dimension here is a modeling choice and the other is an operational choice, we should remove this coupling and provide consistent I/O parity between the two env manager settings.

### Motivation

> #### What is the use case for this feature?
Models that include input data types that are not JSON serializable but are pyarrow serializable fail to predict if loaded into a `spark_udf` with `env_manager = "virtualenv"`, while they do work with `env_manager="local"`. Conversely, if something is JSON serializable but not pyarrow serializable, it will work only with `env_manager = "virtualenv"` and not `env_manager="local"`

This argues for one of two feature approaches:
1. Adopt a body of type regressions against the JSON serialization powering the scoring server, to ensure parity with pyarrow (which is the usual serialization pattern supported in spark)
2. [Preferred, but probably harder] adjust the communication to the Scoring Server to leverage Arrow Flight RPC over JSON RESTful interface. This would delegate parity to the arrow project, and likely also result in increased performance of the scoring server.

> #### Why is this use case valuable to support for MLflow users in general?
Standard spark communication with executors is driven through pyarrow, while communication to the scoring server is through JSON request payload. This causes a lack of parity in model compatibility for `mlflow.pyfunc.spark_udf()` calls when input data is serializable into pyarrow and not json, or vice versa. In addition, if there are differences in the serialization framework (for instance, the treatment of nulls) this can lead to model output changes that result from a strictly operational refactor.

This can be for quite common datatypes; an example of one that works with `env_manager="local"` but not `env_manager = "virtualenv"` is the python base `binary` type, which may for instance be used to represent image media loaded from external storage.

> #### Why is this use case valuable to support for your project(s) or organization?

We have strict policies around copying media outside of governed s3 buckets, and so need to persist a copy in memory to avoid an expensive i/o operation on a GPU executor. Simultaneously, we value the strict environment guarantees provided by `env_manager = "virtualenv"`.

> #### Why is it currently difficult to achieve this use case?

You cannot currently encapsulate models leveraging binary type data using the `virtualenv` eng

### Details

_No response_

### What machine learning domain(s) is this feature request about?

issues.title: [BUG] Cannot remove Trace Tags from the UI

labels.name: area/uiux
labels.description: Front-end, user experience, plotting, JavaScript, JavaScript dev server

issues.body: ### MLflow version 3.5.1 ### System information - **OS Platform and Distribution (e.g., Linux Ubuntu 16.04)**: OS X Tahoe 26.0.1 - **Python version**: 3.11.7 - **yarn version, if running the dev UI**: 4.9.1 (built the UI via `yarn build`) ### Describe the problem Cannot remove tags that were assigned to a trace from the UI. Removing from Python seems to be working, because there it's still using the old v2 endpoint. The stack trace from the server is the following: ``` 2025/11/06 18:13:29 ERROR mlflow.server: Exception on /ajax-api/3.0/mlflow/traces/tr-5cdb4c1edfaec66546907c1c95c3bbcd/tags [DELETE] Traceback (most recent call last): File "/Users/kirill/mlflow/.venv/lib/python3.10/site-packages/flask/app.py", line 1511, in wsgi_app response = self.full_dispatch_request() File "/Users/kirill/mlflow/.venv/lib/python3.10/site-packages/flask/app.py", line 919, in full_dispatch_request rv = self.handle_user_exception(e) File "/Users/kirill/mlflow/.venv/lib/python3.10/site-packages/flask_cors/extension.py", line 176, in wrapped_function return cors_after_request(app.make_response(f(*args, **kwargs))) File "/Users/kirill/mlflow/.venv/lib/python3.10/site-packages/flask/app.py", line 917, in full_dispatch_request rv = self.dispatch_request() File "/Users/kirill/mlflow/.venv/lib/python3.10/site-packages/flask/app.py", line 902, in dispatch_request return self.ensure_sync(self.view_functions[rule.endpoint])(**view_args) # type: ignore[no-any-return] File "/Users/kirill/mlflow/mlflow/server/handlers.py", line 715, in wrapper return func(*args, **kwargs) File "/Users/kirill/mlflow/mlflow/server/handlers.py", line 756, in wrapper return func(*args, **kwargs) TypeError: _delete_trace_tag() got an unexpected keyword argument 'trace_id' ``` I have noticed that the protobuf definition changed between V2 and V3, where V3 has `request_id` instead of `trace_id`. I have tried to make a duplicate of the `mlflow.server.handlers._delete_trace_tag` function with a different name of the argument, which got me to step inside of the function, however, after that I got problems with handling the `key` argument. I assume this is happening because `mlflow.server.handlers._get_request_message` cannot handle this particular request and throws that it doesn't see the `key` argument. Assume this is because this request is different from usual: - DELETE request - No body - Argument is in the query parameter This was as far as I went before it started feeling to me like this is too big for me to dig into myself. ### Steps to reproduce the bug 1) Create a trace and add a span to it 2) Navigate to the trace in the UI 3) Check the tickbox near the trace 4) Open the "Actions" dropdown -> Edit Tags 5) Click on the x near `foo: bar` tag 6) Click on the "Save tags" button to save changes Expected: The selected tag gets deleted Actual: Tag doesn't get deleted ### Code to generate data required to reproduce the bug While running an mlflow server locally: ```python import mlflow mlflow.set_tracking_uri("http://localhost:5000") with mlflow.start_run(): with mlflow.start_span("foo") as sp: print("bar") cl = mlflow.client.MlflowClient() cl.set_trace_tag(sp.request_id, "foo", "bar") ``` ### Is the console panel in DevTools showing errors relevant to the bug? ### Does the network panel in DevTools contain failed requests relevant to the bug? ``` DELETE http://localhost:5000/ajax-api/3.0/mlflow/traces/tr-5cdb4c1edfaec66546907c1c95c3bbcd/tags?key=foo Status Code: 500 ```

issues.title: [BUG] Llama-index tracer crashes when using LLMs that do not report token usage
issues.body:
### Issues Policy acknowledgement

- [x] I have read and agree to submit bug reports in accordance with the [issues policy](https://www.github.com/mlflow/mlflow/blob/master/ISSUE_POLICY.md)

### Where did you encounter this bug?

Local machine

### MLflow version

- Client: 3.5.1
- Tracking server: 3.5.1


### System information

- **OS Platform and Distribution (e.g., Linux Ubuntu 16.04)**: Windows 10
- **Python version**: 3.13.5


### Describe the problem

The llamaindex tracer expects all the LLMs from Llamaindex to return token usage in the `additional_kwargs` field. 
However, not all LLM return these information like the Llamaindex's `OpenAI` class. This causes a KeyError exception that prevents traces data to be logged in async code.

The UI then shows `No trace data available` when attempting to see detailed trace view.

### Tracking information


```python
import asyncio
import logging
import mlflow
from llama_index.core.base.llms.types import ChatMessage

# Must set the logging level to DEBUG to see the error.
logging.getLogger("mlflow.llama_index.tracer").setLevel(logging.DEBUG)

mlflow.llama_index.autolog()

@mlflow.trace
async def call_llm(message: str) -> str:
    llm = GoogleGenAI(model="gemini-2.5-flash-lite", api_key="AIzaSyCntCJ5Xbtrl48Gd4RXCYf0zpcZjuR9F98")
    response = await llm.achat(
        messages=[ChatMessage(role="user", content=message)]
    )
    return str(response)

asyncio.run(call_llm("What is the capital of France?"))
```

issues.body:
### Willingness to contribute

No. I cannot contribute this feature at this time.

### Proposal Summary

When calling langchain with system prompt cached
```json
{
"role": "system",
"content": [{
              "type": "text",
              "text": "always the same(...).",
              "cache_control": {"type": "ephemeral"}}
]
```
I record  in `def on_llm_end(self, response: LLMResult, run_id, **kw)`
under `response.llm_output.get('usage')` the values representing cache hit ratio for Anthropic cache.

```
"cache_read_input_tokens": 15524,
"completion_tokens": 51,
"prompt_tokens": 15667,
"total_tokens": 15718,
"cache_creation_input_tokens": 0
```

Those values are not propagated to `mlflow.trace.tokenUsage`.
I would like them to be traced.


### Motivation

> #### What is the use case for this feature?
Tracking the cache hit ratio to estimate query cost in the inference tables

> #### Why is this use case valuable to support for MLflow users in general?
Seems to be generally useful to track query cost

> #### Why is this use case valuable to support for your project(s) or organization?
Track the query cost

> #### Why is it currently difficult to achieve this use case?
Need to write custom code.

### Details

I assume they should be whitelisted here?
```
_TOKEN_USAGE_KEY_MAPPING = {
    # OpenAI
    "prompt_tokens": TokenUsageKey.INPUT_TOKENS,
    "completion_tokens": TokenUsageKey.OUTPUT_TOKENS,
    "total_tokens": TokenUsageKey.TOTAL_TOKENS,
    # OpenAI Streaming, Anthropic, etc.
    "input_tokens": TokenUsageKey.INPUT_TOKENS,
    "output_tokens": TokenUsageKey.OUTPUT_TOKENS,
}
```

issues.title: [DOC-FIX] Langchain tracing customization
issues.body:
### Willingness to contribute

Yes. I can contribute a documentation fix independently.

### URL(s) with the issue

https://mlflow.org/docs/latest/genai/tracing/integrations/listing/langchain/#customize-tracing-behavior

### Description of proposal (what needs changing)

Existing documentation provides with the example of `CustomLangchainTracer`.
It was not clear for me that it should be added to callbacks like this
```python
config = {"callbacks": [CustomLangchainTracer()]}
workflow.stream(request, config=config)
```
And that mlflow autolog will detect child classes of `MlflowLangchainTracer` in the registered callbacks.
I suggest to explicitly document how to use it. I spend time analysing source code and thinking what is `inheritable_handlers` property of `autolog`. 
I have no previous experience with mlflow tracing so maybe it is simple enough for others? 

Another thing, I have more advanced example of the `RedactedLangchainTracker` that nullifies all inputs, outputs, tool results, stacktraces. It is useful for me to collect token usage without collecting huge (for my Agent with MCP tools) payload about the graph state (that othewise do not fit Databricks inference tables MAX_REQUEST_SIZE_EXCEEDED and MAX_RESPONSE_SIZE_EXCEEDED). I'm willing to share or maybe even include it in docs/examples is there is demand for such example.

issues.title: [BUG] Performance regression in versions 3.3 and above

labels.name: area/model-registry
labels.description: Model registry, model registry APIs, and the fluent client calls for model registry

labels.name: area/tracking
labels.description: Tracking service, tracking client APIs, autologging

issues.body:
### Issues Policy acknowledgement

- [x] I have read and agree to submit bug reports in accordance with the [issues policy](https://www.github.com/mlflow/mlflow/blob/master/ISSUE_POLICY.md)

### Where did you encounter this bug?

Local machine

### MLflow version

- Client: 3.3.2 (tested up to and including 3.5.1)
- Tracking server: 3.3.2 (tested up to and including 3.5.1)


### System information

- **OS Platform and Distribution (e.g., Linux Ubuntu 16.04)**: macOS Sequoia 15.6.1
- **Python version**: 3.12.11


### Describe the problem

While looking at upgrading our setup from mlflow 2 to mlflow 3, we've found what looks like a significant performance regression while logging our large-ish (1 GB+) models to the registry.

The logging takes around 60-70x more time compared to mlflow 2.22.1.

I haven't tested all combinations of model sizes but from what I've seen, some regression seems to occur for small models but it is most pronounced for large models.

Versions 3.0 and 3.1 did not seem to have significant issues; version 3.2 timed out during my tests, version 3.3 and above complete but take an extremely long time.

* This happens when running locally with `mlflow server` or `mlflow ui` with default configuration.
* This happens in the deployed environments with S3 artifact storage and Postgres backend.
* This _does not_ happen when running locally without explicitly launching a tracking server.

Another issue that might or might not be related: I've noticed that downloading artifacts has become up to 10x slower after this upgrade as well.

### Tracking information

<!-- PLEASE KEEP BACKTICKS AND CHECK PREVIEW -->
```shell
MLflow version: 3.3.2
Tracking URI: http://localhost:8080
Artifact URI: mlflow-artifacts:/733624845572122970/538207488ee84711a225ece64f0e1be7/artifacts

System information: Darwin Darwin Kernel Version 24.6.0: Mon Jul 14 11:30:29 PDT 2025; root:xnu-11417.140.69~1/RELEASE_ARM64_T6000
Python version: 3.12.11
MLflow version: 3.3.2
MLflow module location: /Users/myuser/project/.venv/lib/python3.12/site-packages/mlflow/__init__.py
Tracking URI: http://localhost:8080
Registry URI: http://localhost:8080
Active experiment ID: 733624845572122970
Active run ID: 538207488ee84711a225ece64f0e1be7
Active run artifact URI: mlflow-artifacts:/733624845572122970/538207488ee84711a225ece64f0e1be7/artifacts
MLflow environment variables: 
  MLFLOW_EXPERIMENT_ID: 733624845572122970
  MLFLOW_TRACKING_URI: http://localhost:8080
MLflow dependencies: 
  Flask: 3.1.1
  alembic: 1.16.1
  boto3: 1.40.19
  botocore: 1.40.19
  cryptography: 45.0.7
  docker: 7.1.0
  fastapi: 0.118.2
  graphene: 3.4.3
  gunicorn: 23.0.0
  matplotlib: 3.10.3
  mlflow-skinny: 3.3.2
  mlflow-tracing: 3.3.2
  numpy: 2.2.6
  pandas: 2.3.2
  pyarrow: 19.0.1
  scikit-learn: 1.6.1
  scipy: 1.15.3
  sqlalchemy: 2.0.41
  uvicorn: 0.34.3
  virtualenv: 20.31.2
  watchfiles: 1.1.0
```


### Code to reproduce issue

<!-- PLEASE KEEP BACKTICKS AND CHECK PREVIEW -->
This uses a public, 1.3 GB model to reproduce the slow logging. The exact contents do not seem relevant.

On my machine; 2.22.2 takes less than 30 _seconds_, while 3.3.2 takes nearly _30_ minutes.

```
from time import monotonic

import mlflow
from transformers import BertForSequenceClassification, BertTokenizer

mlflow.set_tracking_uri(uri="http://localhost:8080")

model_name = "bert-large-uncased"
model = BertForSequenceClassification.from_pretrained(model_name)
tokenizer = BertTokenizer.from_pretrained(model_name)

class BertPyFunc(mlflow.pyfunc.PythonModel):
    def load_context(self, context):
        pass

    def predict(self, context, model_input):
        pass

model.save_pretrained("./bert_model")
tokenizer.save_pretrained("./bert_tokenizer")

mlflow.set_experiment("performance_regression")
with mlflow.start_run():
    start = monotonic()
    print("Logging model...")
    mlflow.pyfunc.log_model(
        artifact_path="bert_model",

            "tokenizer_path": "./bert_tokenizer"
        },
    )
    end = monotonic()
```

issues.title: [BUG] Not able to use a UC Volume as dfs_tmpdir in mlflow.spark.load_model when running on a Databricks Dedicated cluster

labels.name: area/model-registry
labels.description: Model registry, model registry APIs, and the fluent client calls for model registry

labels.name: area/scoring
labels.description: MLflow Model server, model deployment tools, Spark UDFs

labels.name: area/tracking
labels.description: Tracking service, tracking client APIs, autologging

labels.name: has-closing-pr
labels.description: This issue has a closing PR

issues.body:
### Issues Policy acknowledgement

- [x] I have read and agree to submit bug reports in accordance with the [issues policy](https://www.github.com/mlflow/mlflow/blob/master/ISSUE_POLICY.md)

### Where did you encounter this bug?

Databricks

### MLflow version

- Client: 3.0.1


### System information

- **OS Platform and Distribution**: Databricks Runtime 17.3 LTS ML
- **Python version**: 3.12.3


### Describe the problem

Usage of DBFS root is considered deprecated by Databricks, and best practice is to have it disabled. This means we need to configure `MLFLOW_DFS_TMP`/`dfs_tmpdir` to use a UC Volume instead of default `/tmp/mlflow` in order to successfully use spark-functions `save_model`, `log_model`, and `load_model`. This seems to work fine in most scenarios, but not when executing `load_model` on a compute cluster with Dedicated access mode (which is the only access mode supporting the Databricks Machine Learning Runtime, ref: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/databricks/machine-learning/databricks-runtime-ml#access-mode-for-databricks-runtime-ml-clusters). As shown in the stack trace (source code: https://github.com/mlflow/mlflow/blob/v3.0.1/mlflow/spark/__init__.py#L849-L850), we end up the dbfs-route and hence `/dbfs` is prepended to the `/Volumes/...`-path, resulting in an error when trying to access the Volume (`/dbfs`-prefix is not allowed for accessing Volumes: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/databricks/volumes/#reserved-paths-for-volumes).

It seems the implementation of `load_model` only supports using a UC Volume as `dfs_tmpdir` when using Serverless or a Standard/Shared cluster (ref: https://github.com/mlflow/mlflow/blob/v3.0.1/mlflow/spark/__init__.py#L873-L883). Note that this behavior is different from the implementation of `save_model`. `Save_model` allows us to use a UC Volume as `dfs_tmpdir` also when running on a Dedicated cluster, due to a less restrictive condition (ref: https://github.com/mlflow/mlflow/blob/v3.0.1/mlflow/spark/__init__.py#L811-L816). I would expect the implementation of `save_model` and `load_model` to behave the same when it comes to temporary storage capabilities.

Due to this behavior in `load_model`, we are currently not able to follow Databricks best practices (disable dbfs root) when running MLflow spark on clusters running the Databricks Runtime for Machine Learning.

### Tracking information




### Code to reproduce issue

<!-- PLEASE KEEP BACKTICKS AND CHECK PREVIEW -->
```
import mlflow.spark
from pyspark.ml.classification import LogisticRegression
from pyspark.ml import Pipeline
from pyspark.ml.feature import VectorAssembler

assembler = VectorAssembler(inputCols=["feature1", "feature2"], outputCol="features")
lr = LogisticRegression(featuresCol="features", labelCol="label")
pipeline = Pipeline(stages=[assembler, lr])
df = spark.createDataFrame([
    (1.0, 2.0, 0),
    (3.0, 4.0, 1),
    (5.0, 6.0, 0),
    (7.0, 8.0, 1)
], ["feature1", "feature2", "label"])

model = pipeline.fit(df)

uc_volume = "/Volumes/<some-path>"
model_path = uc_volume + "/my_model"
tmp_dir = uc_volume + "/tmp"

mlflow.spark.save_model(spark_model=model, path=model_path, dfs_tmpdir=tmp_dir)
loaded_model = mlflow.spark.load_model(model_uri=model_path, dfs_tmpdir=tmp_dir)

display(loaded_model.transform(df))
```


### Stack trace

<!-- PLEASE KEEP BACKTICKS AND CHECK PREVIEW -->
```
OSError: [Errno 5] Input/output error: '/dbfs/Volumes'
[Trace ID: 00-62cd1a65183f03d77a4776eed7060ac7-b4642dc791ef09e1-00]
File <command-8992377424363338>, line 23
     20 tmp_dir = uc_volume + "/tmp"
     22 mlflow.spark.save_model(spark_model=model, path=model_path, dfs_tmpdir=tmp_dir)
---> 23 loaded_model = mlflow.spark.load_model(model_uri=model_path, dfs_tmpdir=tmp_dir)
     25 display(loaded_model.transform(df))
File <command-8992377424363338>, line 23
     20 tmp_dir = uc_volume + "/tmp"
     22 mlflow.spark.save_model(spark_model=model, path=model_path, dfs_tmpdir=tmp_dir)
---> 23 loaded_model = mlflow.spark.load_model(model_uri=model_path, dfs_tmpdir=tmp_dir)
     25 display(loaded_model.transform(df))
File /databricks/python/lib/python3.12/site-packages/mlflow/spark/__init__.py:961, in load_model(model_uri, dfs_tmpdir, dst_path)
    959 sparkml_model_uri = append_to_uri_path(model_uri, flavor_conf["model_data"])
```

issues.title: [BUG] `runner.run_streamed` with `handoff` creates separate traces for chained agents
issues.body:
### Issues Policy acknowledgement

- [x] I have read and agree to submit bug reports in accordance with the [issues policy](https://www.github.com/mlflow/mlflow/blob/master/ISSUE_POLICY.md)

### Where did you encounter this bug?

Local machine

### MLflow version

mlflow                             3.5.1



### System information

## üêõ Bug Report: `runner.run_streamed` with `handoff` creates separate traces for chained agents

### üîç Summary

When chaining multiple Agents using the OpenAI Agents SDK **`handoff` mechanism** and executing the sequence via **`runner.run_streamed`**, the expected behavior of a single, continuous trace is not achieved. Instead, each Agent in the chain produces a **separate, independent MLflow Trace**, breaking the end-to-end visibility of the agent execution flow.

### üìù Description

We are utilizing the ` OpenAI Agents SDK `  to build complex workflows where one Agent's output is passed to the next Agent (chained using `handoff`).

When executing this chain using the streaming method, **`runner.run_streamed()`**, the MLflow tracing functionality appears to reset or re-initialize a new run/trace context at the transition point between Agents (i.e., where the `handoff` occurs).

**Expected Behavior:**
The entire sequence of agent calls, from the initial trigger through all subsequent `handoff` steps, should be recorded as a **single, unified MLflow Trace/Run** that captures the entire conversation flow, including intermediate tool calls and final outputs.

**Actual Behavior:**
The execution results in **$N$ distinct MLflow Traces** (where $N$ is the number of agents in the chain). Each trace only captures the activity of the specific Agent responsible for that segment of execution. This makes debugging and analyzing the complete, end-to-end agent logic extremely difficult.

### Describe the problem

Three Agents were connected in series, resulting in three traces

### Tracking information

issues.title: [BUG] Security Vulnerability
issues.body:
Currently, we are facing a critical security vulnerability - which affects MLFlow versions 1.23.0 and newer, including the latest release. This vulnerability arises from unsafe deserailization of untrusted data allowing attackers to execute arbitrary code via maliciously crafted models.

Given the severity of the this issue and its potential for remote exploitation, we are concerned about the lack of a patched version or official mitigation guidance from the MLflow maintainers as of now.

issues.title: [FR] Add trace metadata as OpenTelemetry span attributes

labels.name: domain/genai
labels.description: Feature requests related to GenAI/LLM use cases

labels.name: domain/classical-ml
labels.description: Feature requests for Classical ML use cases

issues.body:
### Willingness to contribute

Yes. I would be willing to contribute this feature with guidance from the MLflow community.

### Proposal Summary

## Allow custom metadata to be added as span attributes in MLflow traces

Hello team!  

Currently, MLflow supports adding metadata to traces, but this metadata is only stored in the MLflow database. It is not propagated as span attributes when exporting traces via an OpenTelemetry collector.

**Proposed Feature**  
Add support for automatically attaching MLflow trace metadata as span attributes, with a configuration option to enable or disable this behavior.



### Motivation

> #### What is the use case for this feature?

This creates a limitation with downstream observability tools. Not possible to filter, search, or visualize traces using metadata, since it is not attached to the spans themselves.

> #### Why is this use case valuable to support for MLflow users in general?

 Enables richer observability and correlation across systems.

> #### Why is this use case valuable to support for your project(s) or organization?

Teams can see critical context (e.g., chat_id, user_id, model_name) directly in distributed tracing backends

> #### Why is it currently difficult to achieve this use case?



### Details

Currently I‚Äôm ~manually attaching a custom SpanProcessor~  I use a post processing hook.

```python
import mlflow

def add_metadata(span: Span) -> None:
    metadata = get_my_metadata()
    span.set_attributes(metadata)

mlflow.tracing.configure(span_processors=[add_metadata])
```

This works, but it would be very helpful to have it directly integrated with  update_current_trace function.

### Description of proposal (what needs changing)

[MLflow docs](https://mlflow.org/docs/latest/genai/datasets/end-to-end-workflow/) direct Databricks users to `databricks-agent`s:

> Databricks Users: This workflow uses MLflow OSS evaluation dataset APIs. For Databricks environments, use the databricks-agents package instead, which provides optimized dataset management integrated with Unity Catalog.

labels.name: domain/platform

issues.body:
### Willingness to contribute

No. I cannot contribute this feature at this time.

### Proposal Summary

Open Telemetry is increasingly adding support for Generative AI data by default in telemetry agents, which is enabling users to capture valuable data across their tech stack that can be used to inform decisions about AI and ML workflows. Most existing services will be monitored by OpenTelemetry agents by default, not the ML flow agent. To enable these users to take advantage of the telemetry data they collect from other services in their generative AI ecosystem, allow ML flow to collect a well documented subset of OpenTelemetry data and automatically enrich visualizations with this data.

### Motivation

> #### What is the use case for this feature?

1. As a AI/ML engineer self hosting ML Flow, I want to use the Open Telemetry data from other services in my tech stack to get better insights into my AI/ML workflows.

2. As an AI/ML engineer, I don't want to concern myself with collecting and managing telemetry. I want a cluster administrator to be able to send external OTEL data to MLFlow for processing, and continue to use the MLFlow tracing agent in my day to day work. I want the data that gets sent to be correlated by trace and span ID in ML flow so that I can attribute it to specific experiments and workflow executions.

3. As a cluster admin configuring how I send data to MLFLow, I would like there to be an MLFlow OTLP Exporter that automatically formats and filters the OTEL data I stream to my MLFlow service.

> #### Why is this use case valuable to support for MLflow users in general?

Hosting ML Flow on your own infrastructure adds significant complexity. Users of MLFlow will not care about all of the telemetry data collected in a cluster, but by integrating telemetry tightly with AI/ML experiments and workflow execution, this is a valuable opportunity to help users reason about their system more easily and understand their results in greater detail.

> #### Why is this use case valuable to support for your project(s) or organization?

In my opinion, bringing MLFlow closer to the OpenTelemetry community is what is best for OpenSource. I want ML Flow to be part of the [AI SIG](https://github.com/open-telemetry/community/blob/main/projects/gen-ai.md) in Open Telemetry and to help make decisions on semantic conventions, contribute AI/ML instrumentation to OTEL agents, and steer OpenTelemetry's AI priorities to benefit both MLFlow and the OpenSource community.

> #### Why is it currently difficult to achieve this use case?

This is not supported or documented. 

### Details

_No response_

issues.title: [BUG] mlflow.register_model drops artifacts in v3

labels.name: area/model-registry
labels.description: Model registry, model registry APIs, and the fluent client calls for model registry

issues.body: ### Issues Policy acknowledgement - [x] I have read and agree to submit bug reports in accordance with the [issues policy](https://www.github.com/mlflow/mlflow/blob/master/ISSUE_POLICY.md) ### Where did you encounter this bug? Other ### MLflow version - Client: v3.5.1 - Tracking server: Managed by Databricks ### System information - **OS Platform and Distribution (e.g., Linux Ubuntu 16.04)**: `python:3.11.9-bookworm` - **Python version**: 3.11 - **yarn version, if running the dev UI**: ### Describe the problem While attempting to migrate to mlflow v3, we've run into a breaking change about `mlflow.register_model`. This is how we register our models: ```python mlflow.register_model( model_uri="", name="", ) ``` Historically, this is how the experiment looked after the call to `register_model`: - `::///model/MLmodel` - `::///model/build/build_meta.json` - `::///model/build/training.tar.gz` - `::///model/conda.yaml` - `::///model/model.pkl` - `::///model/python_env.yaml` - `::///model/requirements.txt` Historically, mlflow would essentially just pick up everything below the experiment runs model folder and **copy** it to the model artifact location like this: - `::///MLmodel` - `::///build/build_meta.json` - `::///build/training.tar.gz` - `::///conda.yaml` - `::///model.pkl` - `::///python_env.yaml` - `::///requirements.txt` This made sense, because the registered model is now essentially an immutable snapshot copy of the experiment run! After testing mlflow v3, we see this behavior. This is how the experiment looks like after the call to `register_model`: - `::///model/build/build_meta.json` - `::///model/build/training.tar.gz` And this is how the model artifact location looks like: - `::///MLmodel` - `::///conda.yaml` - `::///model.pkl` - `::///python_env.yaml` - `::///registered_model_meta` - `::///requirements.txt` It appears that mlflow apparently **moves!!!** some arbitrary collection of model artifacts that databricks deems important from the experiment to the model location! Not only does this mutate the original experiment run, it also breaks our serving processes because critical serving related model artifacts are now missing! The result is, that we need to fix our serving process to kind of inspect artifacts of both the model and the underlying experiment run and kind of merge this back into a healthy state. Even worse, we need to give our serving processes access to both, the storage location behind the UC Catalog, and the Workspace ... Please fix this and revert the previous behavior! ### Tracking information ```shell REPLACE_ME ``` ### Code to reproduce issue The issue can be reproduced as such: ```python """ This script needs to be run with the following env vars: - DATABRICKS_HOST - The Databricks Workspace URL - DATABRICKS_CLIENT_ID - The OAuth2 Client ID of a Service Principal or User - DATABRICKS_CLIENT_SECRET - The OAuth2 Client Secret of a Service Principal or User - EXPERIMENT_NAME - The experiment path inside the Databricks Workspace to use - MODEL_NAME - The fully qualified three dimensional model name inside databricks unity catalog Can be tested with: uv run --python 3.11 --no-project --with 'mlflow[databricks]==3.5.1' --with scikit-learn==1.7.2 foo.py uv run --python 3.11 --no-project --with 'mlflow[databricks]==2.18' --with scikit-learn==1.7.2 foo.py """ import os os.environ["MLFLOW_TRACKING_URI"] = "databricks" os.environ["MLFLOW_REGISTRY_URI"] = "databricks-uc" import tempfile from pathlib import Path import mlflow from mlflow.models.signature import ModelSignature from mlflow.types.schema import ColSpec from mlflow.types.schema import Schema from sklearn.ensemble import RandomForestClassifier DUMMY_SIGNATURE = ModelSignature( inputs=Schema(inputs=[ColSpec(type="float", name="ignore-me")]), outputs=Schema(inputs=[ColSpec(type="float", name="ignore-me")]), ) if __name__ == '__main__': mlflow.set_experiment(experiment_name=os.environ["EXPERIMENT_NAME"]) with mlflow.start_run(run_name=f"hello-mlflow-{mlflow.__version__}") as run: model = RandomForestClassifier(random_state=0) X = [ [1, 2, 3], [11, 12, 13] ] y = [0, 1] fitted_model = model.fit(X, y) with tempfile.TemporaryDirectory() as tmp: # just log some arbirtray file to the experiment run below ./model local_artifact = Path(tmp) / "foo.txt" local_artifact.write_text("hello-world") mlflow.log_artifacts(local_dir=tmp, artifact_path="model") mlflow.sklearn.log_model( fitted_model, artifact_path="model", # cannot use `name` to run the script against both mlflow versions signature=DUMMY_SIGNATURE ) mlflow.register_model( model_uri=f"runs:/{run.info.run_id}/model", name=os.environ["MODEL_NAME"] ) ``` ## MLflow v3 Running the script with mlflow v3 as such: ```shell uv run --python 3.11 --no-project --with 'mlflow[databricks]==3.5.1' --with scikit-learn==1.7.2 foo.py ``` Results in this state inside the Databricks Workspace: ## MLflow v2 Running the script with mlflow v2 as such: ```shell uv run --python 3.11 --no-project --with 'mlflow[databricks]==2.18' --with scikit-learn==1.7.2 foo.py ``` Results in this state inside the Databricks Workspace: The fact that even the UI displays the change in the mlflow version diff makes me somewhat worried, that this is intended behavior üò¨ ### Stack trace ``` REPLACE_ME ``` ### Other info / logs ``` REPLACE_ME ``` ### What component(s) does this bug affect? - [ ] `area/tracking`: Tracking Service, tracking client APIs, autologging - [x] `area/model-registry`: Model Registry service, APIs, and the fluent client calls for Model Registry - [ ] `area/scoring`: MLflow model serving, deployment tools, Spark UDFs - [ ] `area/evaluation`: MLflow model evaluation features, evaluation metrics, and evaluation workflows - [ ] `area/prompt`: MLflow prompt engineering features, prompt templates, and prompt management - [ ] `area/tracing`: MLflow Tracing features, tracing APIs, and LLM tracing functionality - [ ] `area/gateway`: MLflow AI Gateway client APIs, server, and third-party integrations - [ ] `area/projects`: MLproject format, project running backends - [ ] `area/uiux`: Front-end, user experience, plotting - [ ] `area/docs`: MLflow documentation pages

issues.body:
### Willingness to contribute

No. I cannot contribute a documentation fix at this time.

### URL(s) with the issue

https://mlflow.org/docs/latest/genai/getting-started/connect-environment/

### Description of proposal (what needs changing)

This page has an "ACCESS DENIED?" box that is somewhat useful, but the wording and link to the Network Security Guide is less than ideal. A coworker and I were getting the error, found the box, and clicked on it. This pointed us directly to --cors-allowed-origins, and the box seemed to imply that fixing that would fix the issue. However, the actual problem was the --allowed-hosts flag hidden above that.

I would suggest one of the following:

1) Link to the top of https://mlflow.org/docs/latest/self-hosting/security/network in the "ACCESS DENIED?" box, rather than specifically the CORS flag and eliminate the lines "The common cause for this error is the tracking server does not allow requests from your origin to prevent clickjacking attacks. You need to set up an allowlist of CORS origins in the tracking server configuration in this case."

OR

2) Actually mention --allowed-hosts and/or --cors-allowed-origins on https://mlflow.org/docs/latest/genai/getting-started/connect-environment/

issues.title: [BUG] log_metric() no longer working with mlflow.entities.Dataset

labels.name: area/tracking
labels.description: Tracking service, tracking client APIs, autologging

labels.name: has-closing-pr
labels.description: This issue has a closing PR

issues.body:
### Issues Policy acknowledgement

- [x] I have read and agree to submit bug reports in accordance with the [issues policy](https://www.github.com/mlflow/mlflow/blob/master/ISSUE_POLICY.md)

### Where did you encounter this bug?

Local machine

### MLflow version

- Client: 3.5.1
- Tracking server: 3.5.0


### System information

- **OS Platform and Distribution (e.g., Linux Ubuntu 16.04)**: ubuntu 20.04 LTS + MacOS Tahoe 26.0.1
- **Python version**: 3.12.11
- **yarn version, if running the dev UI**: N/A


### Describe the problem

When trying to log a metric under one of the dataset already specified as a run input, I get an `AttributeError: 'Dataset' object has no attribute '_to_mlflow_entity'` since the version 3.5.0

It seems to have been introduced by #18241

I identified a couple of root causes:
1. mlflow.log_metric is expecting a mlflow.data.dataset.Dataset and not an mlflow.entities.dataset.Dataset, despite the former being much harder to reconstruct when one only have access to a run's input, only to then convert it to the latter type. Prior to 3.5.0, using an mlflow.entities.dataset.Dataset worked despite the typing mismatch. (If allowing mlflow.entities.dataset.Dataset as an input to log_metric falls as a feature request, I can create a dedicate issue)
2. mlflow.log_metric fails to recognize that the dataset is already logged as an input to the run, and attempts to log it again.

Regarding the 1st point, if I'm really not supposed to use an mlflow.entities.dataset.Dataset this way, I would appreciate some guidance on how to log a metric under a specific context when I don't have access to the full dataset. I can develop my use case further if needed.

### Tracking information

<!-- PLEASE KEEP BACKTICKS AND CHECK PREVIEW -->
```shell
REPLACE_ME
```


### Code to reproduce issue

<!-- PLEASE KEEP BACKTICKS AND CHECK PREVIEW -->
```python
import mlflow
from mlflow.data.http_dataset_source import HTTPDatasetSource
from mlflow.data.meta_dataset import MetaDataset

with mlflow.start_run() as run:
    dataset_source = HTTPDatasetSource(url="some_uri")
    dataset = MetaDataset(source=dataset_source, name="my_dataset", digest="12345678")

    mlflow.log_input(dataset, context="eval")

    run_data = mlflow.get_run(run.info.run_id)
    dataset_entity = run_data.inputs.dataset_inputs[0].dataset

    mlflow.log_metric("accuracy", 0.95, dataset=dataset_entity)
```


### Stack trace

<!-- PLEASE KEEP BACKTICKS AND CHECK PREVIEW -->
```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/Users/pierretessier/projects/lifen/lifen-ai/tmp.py", line 14, in <module>
    mlflow.log_metric("accuracy", 0.95, dataset=dataset_entity)
  File "/Users/pierretessier/projects/lifen/lifen-ai/.venv/lib/python3.12/site-packages/mlflow/tracking/fluent.py", line 983, in log_metric
    _log_inputs_for_metrics_if_necessary(
  File "/Users/pierretessier/projects/lifen/lifen-ai/.venv/lib/python3.12/site-packages/mlflow/tracking/fluent.py", line 1058, in _log_inputs_for_metrics_if_necessary
    datasets_to_log.append(DatasetInput(matching_dataset._to_mlflow_entity(), tags=[]))
                                        ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
AttributeError: 'Dataset' object has no attribute '_to_mlflow_entity'
```


### Other info / logs

<!-- PLEASE KEEP BACKTICKS AND CHECK PREVIEW -->
```
REPLACE_ME
```

issues.title: [BUG] MLflow S3 Integration prone to bucket sniping

labels.name: has-closing-pr
labels.description: This issue has a closing PR

issues.body:
### Issues Policy acknowledgement

- [x] I have read and agree to submit bug reports in accordance with the [issues policy](https://www.github.com/mlflow/mlflow/blob/master/ISSUE_POLICY.md)

### Where did you encounter this bug?

Local machine

### MLflow version

All

### System information

All


### Describe the problem

Bucket Sniping: https://www.darkreading.com/threat-intelligence/aws-cdk-default-s3-bucket-naming-pattern-lets-adversaries-waltz-into-admin-access

Bucket Ownership Checks: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonS3/latest/userguide/bucket-owner-condition.html

Code Location: https://github.com/kingroryg/mlflow/blob/master/mlflow/store/artifact/s3_artifact_repo.py

Bucket sniping occurs when attackers claim bucket names that applications expect to exist, potentially intercepting data or serving malicious content.

The current default integration of Amazon S3 within MLFlow is prone to bucket sniping attacks. We need to pass a `x-amz-expected-bucket-owner` header along with every S3 API request. I can push in a fix. Curious to hear what the maintainers think of this and have any guidance on the approach that needs to be taken for this. Pls also let me know if this needs to be closed and opened as a security issue. Thanks.

Testing for bucket sniping:
1. Create a bucket name `abc` in account A and give the MLFlow setup to push objects to this bucket.
2. Delete the bucket `abc` from account A and create a bucket with the same name in account B. S3 bucket names are global.
3. Without ownership checks, MLflow will now push objects to bucket `abc` in account B.


### Tracking information

<!-- PLEASE KEEP BACKTICKS AND CHECK PREVIEW -->
```shell
N/A
```


### Code to reproduce issue

We need to use the following parameters (`ExpectedBucketOwner`)  during S3 API calls:

Example: 
```py
s3.put_object(
            Bucket=SECURE_BUCKET,
            Key='mlflow/model.pkl',
            Body=b'model data',
            ExpectedBucketOwner=ACCOUNT_ID
        )
```



POC:

```py
import boto3
import mlflow
import os

# Predictable bucket name
PREDICTABLE_BUCKET = "mycompany-mlflow-prod-2024"

# Random bucket name  
SECURE_BUCKET = "mlflow-a7f3k9x2-artifacts"
ACCOUNT_ID = "XXXXXXXXXXXX"

def vulnerable_setup():
    """Vulnerable MLflow setup - attacker could claim this bucket"""

    
    # This could send data to attacker's bucket if they claimed the name
    mlflow.set_tracking_uri("sqlite:///mlflow.db")
    
    with mlflow.start_run():
        mlflow.log_param("model", "vulnerable")
        mlflow.log_artifact("model.pkl")  # Goes to potentially hostile bucket!

def secure_setup_with_ownership_check():
    """Secure setup with bucket ownership verification"""

    
    s3_client = boto3.client('s3')
    
    # Set expected bucket owner for all S3 operations
    def put_object_secure(bucket, key, body):
        return s3_client.put_object(
            Bucket=bucket,
            Key=key, 
            Body=body,
            ExpectedBucketOwner=ACCOUNT_ID  # Ownership check!
        )
    
    def get_object_secure(bucket, key):
        return s3_client.get_object(
            Bucket=bucket,
            Key=key,
            ExpectedBucketOwner=ACCOUNT_ID  # Ownership check!
        )
    
    try:
        # Test ownership before using bucket
        s3_client.head_bucket(
            Bucket=SECURE_BUCKET,
            ExpectedBucketOwner=ACCOUNT_ID
        )

        
        # Now safe to use MLflow
        os.environ['MLFLOW_S3_IGNORE_TLS'] = 'false'
        mlflow.set_tracking_uri("sqlite:///mlflow.db")
        
        with mlflow.start_run():
            mlflow.log_param("model", "secure")
            # MLflow will use bucket with ownership checks
            
    except s3_client.exceptions.ClientError as e:
        if e.response['Error']['Code'] == 'BucketOwnershipControlsNotFound':
            raise Exception("Bucket security check failed")

def boto3_with_ownership_headers():
    """Direct boto3 usage with ownership headers"""
    s3 = boto3.client('s3')
    
    try:
        # All operations include ownership verification
        s3.put_object(
            Bucket=SECURE_BUCKET,
            Key='mlflow/model.pkl',
            Body=b'model data',
            ExpectedBucketOwner=ACCOUNT_ID
        )
        
        response = s3.get_object(
            Bucket=SECURE_BUCKET, 
            Key='mlflow/model.pkl',
            ExpectedBucketOwner=ACCOUNT_ID
        )
        
        
    except Exception as e:
        print(f"Ownership check failed: {e}")

if __name__ == "__main__":
    
    # Show vulnerable approach
    # vulnerable_setup()  # Commented to avoid actual execution
    
    # Show secure approach
    secure_setup_with_ownership_check()
    boto3_with_ownership_headers()

```

### Stack trace

N/A

### Other info / logs

_No response_

issues.title: üì¢ NOTICE: Filesystem backend deprecation üì¢
issues.body:
## What's Being Deprecated?

- The filesystem backend (e.g., `tracking_uri='./mlruns'`) is deprecated. The database backend (e.g., `tracking_uri='sqlite:///mlruns.db'`) will be the new default.
- Filesystem **artifact** storage remains fully supported and can continue to pair with a database backend.

## Why deprecate Filesystem Backend?

The filesystem backend is deprecated due to:

- **Maintenance Burden**

  - Every feature requires dual implementation (filesystem + database), significantly increasing development and testing time
  - Supporting both filesystem and database storage backends slows down development and increases the risk of bugs

- **Limited Features & Poor UX**

  - Many new MLflow features are not supported in the filesystem backend. Since the filesystem backend is currently the default, these features are not available out-of-the-box, creating an inconvenient experience for users who need them

    | Feature                            | File Backend | Database Backend |
    | ---------------------------------- | :----------: | :--------------: |
    | Experiments / Tags                 |      ‚úÖ      |        ‚úÖ        |
    | Runs (info, params, metrics, tags) |      ‚úÖ      |        ‚úÖ        |
    | Run inputs/outputs                 |      ‚úÖ      |        ‚úÖ        |
    | Logged models                      |      ‚úÖ      |        ‚úÖ        |
    | Traces (metadata, assessments)     |      ‚úÖ      |        ‚úÖ        |
    | Model registry                     |      ‚úÖ      |        ‚úÖ        |
    | Trace spans (OTel data)            |      ‚ûñ      |        ‚úÖ        |
    | Evaluation datasets / results      |      ‚ûñ      |        ‚úÖ        |
    | Model registry webhooks            |      ‚ûñ      |        ‚úÖ        |
    | Registered-model scorers           |      ‚ûñ      |        ‚úÖ        |

- **Security Risks**

  - Path traversal vulnerabilities have a larger attack surface than database-backed systems
  - Relies on OS-level file permissions which are inconsistent across platforms and harder to audit

- **Performance Issues**

  - Degrades significantly with a high volume of runs/experiments/models
  - File system operations don't scale well compared to indexed database queries

## Timeline

**Note: The timeline below is tentative and subject to change based on community feedback.**

| Event                     | MLflow Version | Target date    |
| :------------------------ | :------------- | :------------- |
| Add a deprecation warning | 3.6            | Early Nov 2025 |
| Switch defaults to sqlite | 3.7            | Early Dec 2025 |

## FAQ

- **How will I know if I'm using the filesystem backend?**

  - If you don't explicitly set a tracking URI, or if you use `mlflow.set_tracking_uri("./mlruns")` or similar file paths, you're using the filesystem backend.

- **What will happen to my existing data?**

  - Your existing data will remain intact. We'll provide a migration tool to help you transfer your data from the filesystem backend to SQLite when it's ready.

- **Will this affect my workflows?**

  - The change is primarily in how metadata is stored. Your code will need minimal changes (updating the tracking URI). Artifact storage and most MLflow APIs remain the same.

- **Can I continue using the filesystem backend?**

  - Yes, the filesystem backend will continue to work with deprecation warnings. We're gathering community feedback before making any further changes.

## We Want Your Feedback

Before proceeding, we want to hear from the community:

- How would this change impact your workflows?
- What challenges do you anticipate with migration?
- Are there scenarios where the filesystem backend is critical for you?

Please share your feedback, concerns, or suggestions in the comments below.

issues.title: [BUG] Provide a way to load or retrieve prompts logged with a model in mlflow.pyfunc
issues.body:
### Issues Policy acknowledgement

- [x] I have read and agree to submit bug reports in accordance with the [issues policy](https://www.github.com/mlflow/mlflow/blob/master/ISSUE_POLICY.md)

### Where did you encounter this bug?

Local machine

### MLflow version

- Client: 1.x.y
- Tracking server: 3.5.1


### System information

- **OS Platform and Distribution (e.g., Linux Ubuntu 16.04)**: windows
- **Python version**: 3.11.5
- **yarn version, if running the dev UI**:


### Describe the problem

The current implementation of mlflow.pyfunc.log_model() allows users to specify prompts through the prompts argument when logging a model.

But the documentation does not explain how to access or load the prompts variable within the user script (e.g., dummy_model.py). Since the user has already chosen to log the prompt along with the model, there should ideally be a way to retrieve the prompt_uri directly from the logged model. This functionality is not mentioned in the current documentation, and the docstring for the prompts argument also lacks clarity on how it can be utilized.

While it is possible to manually pass the prompt_uri alongside the model input during inference, this feels counterintuitive‚Äîespecially since the prompt was already associated with the model at logging time. If such functionality does not currently exist, this could be considered as a feature request to introduce a utility that allows users to load and list the prompts logged with the model during the run.

### Tracking information

MLflow version: 3.5.1
Tracking URI: http://localhost:5000/

### Code to reproduce issue

For example:

dummy_model.py
```
import mlflow
import os
from mlflow.pyfunc import PythonModel
from langchain_google_genai import ChatGoogleGenerativeAI
from mlflow.models import set_model


class LangchainModel(PythonModel):
    def __init__(self):
        super().__init__()

    def load_context(self, context):
        print("Loading context")
        self.llm = ChatGoogleGenerativeAI(
            model="gemini-2.5-flash-lite",
            temperature=0,
            max_tokens=None,
            timeout=None,
            max_retries=2,
        )

    def predict(self, context, model_input, params=None) -> str:
        print("Received context: ", context)
        print("Received Input: ", model_input)
        print("Received Params: ", params)
       prompt_uri = "prompts:/dummy_prompt/1"  # hardcoded prompt uri - should be retrieved dynamically from the logged model
        prompt_template = mlflow.genai.load_prompt(prompt_uri).template
        prompt = prompt_template.format(topic=model_input)
        print("Prompt: ", prompt)
        response = self.llm.invoke(prompt)
        print(response)
        return response.content


set_model(LangchainModel())

```

llm.py
```
import mlflow

mlflow.set_tracking_uri("http://localhost:5000")

dummy_prompt = "Tell me a joke about {topic}"

# register the prompt
prompt_uri = mlflow.genai.register_prompt(
    name="dummy_prompt",
    template=dummy_prompt,
)

with mlflow.start_run(run_name="langchain_model"):
    model_info = mlflow.pyfunc.log_model(
        name="dummy_model",
        python_model="dummy_model.py",
        prompts=[prompt_uri],
    )

model = mlflow.pyfunc.load_model(model_info.model_uri)
model.predict("jungle") 
```


### Stack trace

Instead of requiring the prompt to be passed during inference, a utility method such as `self.get_prompts()` should return the prompts that were logged along with the model.


### Other info / logs

<!-- PLEASE KEEP BACKTICKS AND CHECK PREVIEW -->
```
REPLACE_ME
```

issues.body:
### Issues Policy acknowledgement

- [x] I have read and agree to submit bug reports in accordance with the [issues policy](https://www.github.com/mlflow/mlflow/blob/master/ISSUE_POLICY.md)

### Where did you encounter this bug?

Local machine

### MLflow version

- Client: 3.5.1
- Tracking server: 1.x.y


### System information

- **OS Platform and Distribution (e.g., Linux Ubuntu 16.04)**: Windows
- **Python version**: 3.11.5
- **yarn version, if running the dev UI**:


### Describe the problem

When using `mlflow.pyfunc.load_model()` to load a custom `PythonModel`, the params argument passed to the `predict()` method is not propagated to the underlying model‚Äôs `predict(context, model_input, params=None)` implementation. This causes any external parameters (such as configuration values or runtime options) provided via params to be ignored during local inference.

### Tracking information

MLflow version: 3.5.1
Tracking URI: http://localhost:5000/
Artifact URI: mlflow-artifacts:/0/6a0e79b8537e485f9767213894cdde08/artifacts


### Code to reproduce issue

`dummy_model.py`
```
import mlflow
import os
from mlflow.pyfunc import PythonModel
from langchain_google_genai import ChatGoogleGenerativeAI
from mlflow.models import set_model


class LangchainModel(PythonModel):
    def __init__(self):
        super().__init__()

    def load_context(self, context):
        print("Loading context")
        self.llm = ChatGoogleGenerativeAI(
            model="gemini-2.5-flash-lite",
            temperature=0,
            max_tokens=None,
            timeout=None,
            max_retries=2,
        )

    def predict(self, context, model_input, params=None) -> str:
        print("Received context: ", context)
        print("Received Input: ", model_input)
        print("Received Params: ", params)

        # Resolve prompt URI from params ‚Üí env var ‚Üí fallback
        prompt_uri = None
        if isinstance(params, dict):
            prompt_uri = (
                params.get("prompt_uri")
                or params.get("prompt")
                or params.get("uri")
            )
        if not prompt_uri:
            prompt_uri = os.getenv("PROMPT_URI") or os.getenv("MLFLOW_PROMPT_URI")
        if not prompt_uri:
            prompt_uri = "prompts:/dummy_prompt/1"

        prompt_template = mlflow.genai.load_prompt(prompt_uri).template
        prompt = prompt_template.format(topic=model_input)
        print("Prompt: ", prompt)
        response = self.llm.invoke(prompt)
        print(response)
        return response.content


set_model(LangchainModel())

```

llm.py
```
import mlflow

mlflow.set_tracking_uri("http://localhost:5000")

dummy_prompt = "Tell me a joke about {topic}"

# register the prompt
prompt_uri = mlflow.genai.register_prompt(
    name="dummy_prompt",
    template=dummy_prompt,
)

with mlflow.start_run(run_name="langchain_model"):
    model_info = mlflow.pyfunc.log_model(
        name="dummy_model",
        python_model="dummy_model.py",
        prompts=[prompt_uri],
    )

model = mlflow.pyfunc.load_model(model_info.model_uri)
model.predict("jungle", params={"prompt_uri": "prompts:/dummy_prompt/1"})

```



### Stack trace

```
Received Input:  jungle
Received Params:  {}
```

Receiving empty params in the predict method

### Other info / logs

Interestingly, when I create an object of the implemented class and invoke the predict method, the params value is getting passed.

```
from dummy_model import LangchainModel

langchain_model = LangchainModel()
context = None
langchain_model.load_context(context)
langchain_model.predict(context = context,model_input="jungle", params={"prompt_uri": "prompts:/dummy_prompt/1"})
```

Logs:
```
Received Input:  jungle
Received Params:  {'prompt_uri': 'prompts:/dummy_prompt/1'}
```

issues.title: [BUG] Experiment listing page pagination broken after updating search criteria

labels.name: area/uiux
labels.description: Front-end, user experience, plotting, JavaScript, JavaScript dev server

labels.name: has-closing-pr
labels.description: This issue has a closing PR

issues.body: ### MLflow version 3.5.0 ### System information - **OS Platform and Distribution (e.g., Linux Ubuntu 16.04)**: Linux Debian Trixie - **Python version**: 3.19.9 - **yarn version, if running the dev UI**: ### Describe the problem Hello mlflow devs, I'm reporting a UI bug that I found in the new post-3.2.0 experiments listing page. The new UI is much improved and much appreciated, but I did notice that sometimes I'm failing to find an experiment that I *know* is there (i.e., I can get there by adding the experiment number to the URL) via an exact name. After some fiddling with browser dev tools, I think I realized the problem: When I add or update a search name filter in the UI text box, the UI will add this additional filter criteria to the search query. **However, it will not reset the pagination token.** This is problematic because if the thing you're looking for only exists **before** the current pagination token, you'll get a "No results found" screen with no recourse to to back to the first page (the pagination UI will be hidden in this case). Only with a browser page refresh can you get rid of your current pagination token and start over. _How this presented to me initially is that:_ when you have a ton of experiments, and you're paging through them, updating search criteria as you go, sometimes (seemingly random) you'll just get the "No results found" screen even though you know for sure it should exist. Tweaking the search string will do often do nothing. But once you refresh the page, mysteriously you'll be able to find that experiment again. ### Steps to reproduce the bug 1. Make sure you have plenty of experiments to paginate over. Go to the experiments overview listing page 2. Pick an experiment on the first page and copy its exact name 3. Click "next page" several times to navigate forward 4. Now paste in the experiment name you picked in (2) into the search box. It should fail to find the experiment and you'll see the "No results found" screen, with no way to navigate back to the first page 5. Refresh the browser page, and type in the search criteria again. You should now be able to find the experiment. ### Code to generate data required to reproduce the bug _No response_ ### Is the console panel in DevTools showing errors relevant to the bug? _No response_ ### Does the network panel in DevTools contain failed requests relevant to the bug? Query request for experiment listing after paginating for a bit: Now type in a search keyword, and press enter. The new query request retains the old pagination token

issues.title: [BUG] Plugin Registration Fails in MLflow >= 3.5.0 Due to Internal EvaluationDataset Import Error

labels.name: area/model-registry
labels.description: Model registry, model registry APIs, and the fluent client calls for model registry

labels.name: area/tracking
labels.description: Tracking service, tracking client APIs, autologging

labels.name: has-closing-pr
labels.description: This issue has a closing PR

issues.body:
### Issues Policy acknowledgement

- [x] I have read and agree to submit bug reports in accordance with the [issues policy](https://www.github.com/mlflow/mlflow/blob/master/ISSUE_POLICY.md)

### Where did you encounter this bug?

Other

### MLflow version

- Client: 3.5.1
- Tracking server: 1.x.y - not installed


### System information

- **OS Platform and Distribution (e.g., Linux Ubuntu 16.04)**: python-3.11-slim docker image
- **Python version**: 3.11.0
- **yarn version, if running the dev UI**:


### Describe the problem

When attempting to use a custom tracking store and model registry store plugin defined via pyproject.toml entry points, MLflow fails to register the custom URI schemes. This occurs in MLflow versions 3.5.0 and 3.5.1 when running with Python 3.11.

Environment:

MLflow Version: 3.5.1 (also tested and fails with 3.5.0)

Python Version: 3.11.x (installed via python:3.11-slim Docker image)

Operating System: Linux (within Docker container)

Plugin: Custom plugin installed via pip install -e . (source included below if possible/relevant)

Steps to Reproduce:

Define a custom tracking store and/or model registry store plugin (inheriting from RestStore or SqlAlchemyStore).

Define entry points for the plugin in its pyproject.toml (e.g., under [project.entry-points."mlflow.tracking_store"]).

Install the plugin in an environment with MLflow 3.5.0 or 3.5.1 and Python 3.11.

Attempt to start the MLflow server or use an MLflow client configured with the custom store URI.

Observed Behavior:

During MLflow startup (specifically when processing entry points), the following warning appears multiple times:

/usr/local/lib/python3.11/site-packages/mlflow/tracking/_tracking_service/utils.py:205: UserWarning: Failure attempting to register store for scheme "<your-scheme>": cannot import name 'EvaluationDataset' from 'mlflow.entities' (/usr/local/lib/python3.11/site-packages/mlflow/entities/__init__.py)
  _tracking_store_registry.register_entrypoints()
Subsequently, attempting to use the custom store URI (e.g., <your-scheme>://...) results in an error like:

mlflow.exceptions.MlflowException: Could not find entry point for tracking store scheme '<your-scheme>'
or

mlflow.tracking.registry.UnsupportedModelRegistryStoreURIException: Model registry functionality is unavailable; got unsupported URI '<your-scheme>://...'
Expected Behavior:

MLflow should successfully register the plugin's store schemes via the entry points without the EvaluationDataset import warning, allowing the custom URIs to be used.

Analysis:

The custom plugin code does not import EvaluationDataset from mlflow.entities directly. The codebase has been verified.

The mlflow/entities/__init__.py file in MLflow 3.5.x uses __getattr__ for lazy loading of EvaluationDataset to prevent import errors if mlflow.data dependencies are missing.

The error originates from within MLflow's plugin registration code (mlflow/tracking/_tracking_service/utils.py during the register_entrypoints call).

It appears that the plugin registration process in MLflow 3.5.x incorrectly tries to access mlflow.entities.EvaluationDataset in a way that either bypasses or conflicts with the intended lazy loading mechanism, causing the import failure and preventing the plugin from loading successfully.

Adding pandas explicitly as a dependency did not resolve the issue.

This seems to be an internal bug within MLflow's plugin discovery/loading mechanism in versions 3.5.0 and 3.5.1.

issues.body:
### Willingness to contribute

Yes. I can contribute this feature independently.

### Proposal Summary

Currently, the copy and toggle word-wrap buttons in documentation code blocks are not sticky. This means that when a user scrolls through a large code block, they need to scroll back up to access these buttons. Additionally, there is no visible language label on the code snippet.

### Motivation

> #### What is the use case for this feature?
Adding this feature helps users copy code instantly, even in long code blocks, without having to scroll back up to access the copy button. Additionally, displaying the language label improves readability and clarity of the code snippet.
> #### Why is this use case valuable to support for MLflow users in general?
This enhancement improves user experience (UX) for all documentation readers. Users can easily copy code or toggle word wrap without having to scroll, and the language label makes code snippets more understandable, especially in multi-language tutorials or examples.
> #### Why is this use case valuable to support for your project(s) or organization?
For teams building ML workflows using MLflow, quick access to code snippets and clear identification of languages is essential for efficiency and clarity. This reduces friction when referencing documentation for real-world implementations.


### Details

I have already implemented this feature. Since MLflow docs use Docusaurus, I swizzled the CodeBlock component using wrapping (instead of ejecting) and added a new React component, ContentHeader, inside the CodeBlock folder. This component includes both the buttons and the language label at the top of the code block, with sticky behavior for better UX.

If the maintainers feel this enhancement is valuable, I am happy to submit a PR for review.

### What machine learning domain(s) is this feature request about?

- [ ] `domain/genai`: LLMs, Agents, and other GenAI-related use cases

issues.title: [BUG]  Model Registry shows no metadata when registering models through UI

labels.name: area/uiux
labels.description: Front-end, user experience, plotting, JavaScript, JavaScript dev server
